author: nanalakshmanan
body:
Describe is currently not an approved verb. However it is widely used in the AWS CLI. The way the AWS PowerShell modules get around this is by changing the noun to include a list. 

Here is an example of the AWS CLI and PowerShell equivalent for describe

```
PS /> aws ssm describe-automation-executions                                    
```

```PowerShell
PS /> Get-SSMAutomationExecutionList 
```

Here is an example for AWS CLI and PowerShell example for the Get API

```
PS /> aws ssm get-automation-execution  
```

```PowerShell
Get-SSMAutomationExecution
```
Essentially, you do a describe by doing a Get and adding List to the noun. This can be avoided and the command can be truly PowerShell style if Describe is an approved verb.

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
`Describe` to me is an active verb, not a passive one when I see the word I think if will be defining or scaffolding something. 

To me, `describe-automation-executions` and `get-automation-execution` should both be `Get-SSMAutomationExecution` where the default of `Get-SSMAutomationExecution` would return all and `Get-SSMAutomationExecution -ExecutionId $value` or something would return the specific one.

comments.author: FireInWinter
nightroman
comments.body:
> The "Show" verb "Makes a resource visible to the user. This verb is paired with Hide."

In reality, `Show` is used almost as authors want and find it suitable. I never saw it paired with `Hide` yet, too.

> This doesn't match with how AWS uses "describe".

I am not talking about AWS commands (I do not know them). I am talking about `Show` as a possible alternative to `Describe` or `Get-XList` in general.

title: Add "Describe" as an approved Verb
